author: @Fahadsheikh-k4f

text:
Laconic (adjective) 

Meaning:
Using very few words; concise to the point of seeming blunt or mysterious. A laconic person or statement is short and direct, often without extra detail or explanation.

Synonyms (most relevant): concise, terse, brief, succinct, curt
Antonyms: verbose, wordy, talkative, long-winded


---

Real-life examples:

1. Entrepreneurs: When asked about his company‚Äôs success, Elon Musk gave a laconic reply: ‚ÄúWe build rockets.‚Äù


2. Hollywood: Clint Eastwood‚Äôs characters are often laconic‚Äîhe says just enough to get the point across.


3. Military: A soldier giving a laconic update: ‚ÄúMission complete. No casualties.‚Äù


4. Startups: A founder pitching to investors with a laconic line: ‚ÄúWe solve payment problems‚Äîglobally.‚Äù


5. Everyday life: Your friend texts you a laconic ‚ÄúK‚Äù instead of a full sentence.
author: @RanchoddasShamaldaschanchad

text:
Dr. Ananya Mishra advised the OpenAI CEO to respond in a laconic manner when addressing ethical concerns.
Her reasoning was blunt: ‚ÄúPeople are basically dumb‚Äîsay too much, and they‚Äôll twist your words until you‚Äôre the villain.‚Äù
+-------+
|  YES  |
+-------+
Short & simple ‚Äî that‚Äôs laconic.
author: @RanchoddasShamaldaschanchad

text: Sorry but I couldn't imagine this ever taking the place of cars.  Humanity can't drive on a flat surface and just worry about left and right, forwards and backwards much less having to worry about up and down as well.  Humanity is stupid.  As a former software engineer we had a phrase we lived by when creating applications: "Never underestimate the stupidity of the user".  Besides...if the average Joe ever got their hands on something like that....won't take long for someone to get their limbs or head chopped off by the propellers...
